description: GNS3 is a free graphical network simulator capable of emulating a number of network devices. This makes it possible for anyone to quickly and easily spin up network hardware for testing and educational purposes without the heavy expense of physical hardware. Supported devices include Cisco routers and firewalls, Juniper routers, and frame-relay switches.
name: GNS3
subtitle: Router emulation software

episodes.title: What is GNS3?
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:05,374
[NOISE] We get a lot of questions at

2
00:00:05,374 --> 00:00:11,119
ITProTV about how best to study for

3
00:00:11,119 --> 00:00:14,099
the Cisco exams.

4
00:00:14,099 --> 00:00:19,291
If you're working on your CCNA, CCNP,
even your CCIE, those certifications,

5
00:00:19,291 --> 00:00:23,375
they really require hands on
experience with Cisco equipment.

6
00:00:23,375 --> 00:00:25,240
What if you don't have
that available though?

7
00:00:25,240 --> 00:00:29,032
Well there's a really neat product
out there that can help with that and

8
00:00:29,032 --> 00:00:30,178
it's called GNS3.

9
00:00:30,178 --> 00:00:32,980
One of the nice thing about
GNS3 is it is completely free.

10
00:00:32,980 --> 00:00:35,920
It doesn't cost you any money,
so why not use it?

11
00:00:35,920 --> 00:00:38,532
So this series of videos
that we're going to film,

12
00:00:38,532 --> 00:00:42,537
they're gonna show you what GNS3 is,
how it works, how to use it and be able to

13
00:00:42,537 --> 00:00:46,760
build up a lab environment to study and
practice to get ready for your exams.

14
00:00:46,760 --> 00:00:49,821
It's really neat stuff and
it's really not that hard to get set up.

15
00:00:50,890 --> 00:00:53,800
Let's start off real high level though,
what is GNS3?

16
00:00:54,870 --> 00:00:59,420
Deep down inside of it at its heart,
GNS3 is really just a graphically user

17
00:00:59,420 --> 00:01:03,625
interface for
another product called Dynamips.

18
00:01:03,625 --> 00:01:07,100
Dynamips is the actual heart and
soul of this product.

19
00:01:07,100 --> 00:01:11,707
What it is, is years ago, it's a long
time, a good eight to ten years ago,

20
00:01:11,707 --> 00:01:16,650
someone sat down and they wrote
a hardware emulator for Cisco equipment.

21
00:01:16,650 --> 00:01:20,050
If you crack open your average Cisco
router, you'll find that they have

22
00:01:20,050 --> 00:01:25,308
Intel processors and RAM and standard
components like what you'd find in a PC.

23
00:01:25,308 --> 00:01:27,470
Granted it's a proprietary motherboard but

24
00:01:27,470 --> 00:01:30,950
the majority of the components
are just standard components.

25
00:01:30,950 --> 00:01:34,830
So, they wrote this emulator to
emulate that set of hardware so

26
00:01:34,830 --> 00:01:40,180
you could run the actual Cisco IOS,
on this emulated platform.

27
00:01:40,180 --> 00:01:43,980
Well, Dynamips did a pretty good job,
but it was command line only,

28
00:01:43,980 --> 00:01:45,850
so it wasn't very user-friendly.

29
00:01:45,850 --> 00:01:50,711
So the GNS3 project was started to
create a graphical user interface for

30
00:01:50,711 --> 00:01:52,313
the Dynamips utility.

31
00:01:52,313 --> 00:01:54,754
And it's still Dynamips is under the hood,
but

32
00:01:54,754 --> 00:01:57,696
the graphical user interface
kind of covers all that up.

33
00:01:57,696 --> 00:02:00,755
And so a lot of people look at GNS3
as being a full total product, and

34
00:02:00,755 --> 00:02:04,310
it's actually made up of
several different components.

35
00:02:04,310 --> 00:02:06,160
But, you don't have to worry about that.

36
00:02:06,160 --> 00:02:09,990
We can download and install GNS3,
have it up and running, and

37
00:02:09,990 --> 00:02:12,670
start emulating Cisco hardware.

38
00:02:12,670 --> 00:02:15,890
Now, notice I'm saying emulate,
not simulate.

39
00:02:15,890 --> 00:02:19,340
There's a lot of companies out there that
do simulators, like the Boson NetiSm.

40
00:02:19,340 --> 00:02:20,770
And they're perfectly good products.

41
00:02:20,770 --> 00:02:24,458
But on those, you're not actually
working with the Cisco IOS.

42
00:02:24,458 --> 00:02:27,620
You're usually interacting with
something like a Java application.

43
00:02:27,620 --> 00:02:30,180
You type a command,
it parses your command, and

44
00:02:30,180 --> 00:02:33,230
it gives you canned output
that reflects what you typed.

45
00:02:33,230 --> 00:02:36,950
So when you type show version, it's not
actually checking what IOS version you're

46
00:02:36,950 --> 00:02:38,000
running and displaying that.

47
00:02:38,000 --> 00:02:40,680
Instead it's got this canned
output that it feeds you.

48
00:02:40,680 --> 00:02:42,470
The problem with simulators,

49
00:02:42,470 --> 00:02:45,860
they only support the commands
that the developers put in there.

50
00:02:45,860 --> 00:02:49,270
So if you wanna run a command that's
outside of the scope of the CCNA course,

51
00:02:49,270 --> 00:02:51,160
for example, it's not gonna work.

52
00:02:51,160 --> 00:02:52,790
Right?
Now I say that's the problem.

53
00:02:52,790 --> 00:02:53,720
It's not really a problem.

54
00:02:53,720 --> 00:02:56,460
If you're studying for the exam,
those simulators are great.

55
00:02:56,460 --> 00:03:00,420
They usually come prepackaged with labs,
and they're a really valuable resource.

56
00:03:00,420 --> 00:03:01,849
I've used the Boson NetSim myself.

57
00:03:01,849 --> 00:03:03,276
I really like the product.

58
00:03:03,276 --> 00:03:08,589
But an emulator, with an emulator,
you run the actual Cisco IOS.

59
00:03:08,589 --> 00:03:09,910
Every command works.

60
00:03:09,910 --> 00:03:13,130
Doesn't matter if it's on the exam or
not, all the commands work.

61
00:03:13,130 --> 00:03:16,382
And it's the real IOS so
it's not like you're running a command and

62
00:03:16,382 --> 00:03:17,533
you get canned output.

63
00:03:17,533 --> 00:03:21,970
You get output that's reflecting what's
going on in that router at that time.

64
00:03:21,970 --> 00:03:24,723
So, there's the real value of an emulator.

65
00:03:24,723 --> 00:03:28,584
You can use GNS3 to study to get ready for
the exams, you can use it to mock up

66
00:03:28,584 --> 00:03:32,240
networks to get ready for
some kind of deployment in production.

67
00:03:32,240 --> 00:03:34,456
You can do all sorts of
really cool things in it.

68
00:03:34,456 --> 00:03:35,453
It's a neat product, and

69
00:03:35,453 --> 00:03:37,640
the fact that it's free is
really just icing on the cake.

70
00:03:37,640 --> 00:03:40,018
All right,
if you've never heard of it before,

71
00:03:40,018 --> 00:03:41,824
the website is really easy to get to.

72
00:03:41,824 --> 00:03:47,524
It's GNS3.net, and so
that's where I'm at right now is GNS3.net.

73
00:03:47,524 --> 00:03:49,365
Their web page is fairly Spartan.

74
00:03:49,365 --> 00:03:51,087
Not a whole lot of stuff on here, and

75
00:03:51,087 --> 00:03:54,010
it really centers around
getting you that software.

76
00:03:54,010 --> 00:03:57,223
They give a description here and
they tell you it's an intuitive

77
00:03:57,223 --> 00:04:00,628
graphical user interface and
it runs on top of multiple emulators.

78
00:04:00,628 --> 00:04:02,200
Dynamips is the main one.

79
00:04:02,200 --> 00:04:04,360
That's the Cisco IOS emulator.

80
00:04:04,360 --> 00:04:05,292
But it does more.

81
00:04:05,292 --> 00:04:09,759
You'll see there's a VirtualBox and
a QEMU emulator too.

82
00:04:09,759 --> 00:04:11,176
Why do we need those?

83
00:04:11,176 --> 00:04:15,339
Well, you'll see that it adds Cisco ASA
and Pix support, so if you want to

84
00:04:15,339 --> 00:04:19,930
do Cisco firewalls, it also allows
you to do things like Juniper, Junos.

85
00:04:19,930 --> 00:04:22,582
If you wanna learn Juniper routers,
you can bring those up.

86
00:04:22,582 --> 00:04:26,029
But they run on different types of
hardware than what Cisco routers do, so

87
00:04:26,029 --> 00:04:27,590
they don't use Dynamips.

88
00:04:27,590 --> 00:04:31,470
They use VirtualBox and QEMU to
emulate the hardware needed for them.

89
00:04:31,470 --> 00:04:32,248
It's a little bit different.

90
00:04:32,248 --> 00:04:33,940
Now you can do it all at once though.

91
00:04:33,940 --> 00:04:38,493
So you could have Cisco IOS routers
running by the Cisco ASA, running right by

92
00:04:38,493 --> 00:04:43,627
a Junos router, you know you can have that
flexibility, it's really, really cool.

93
00:04:43,627 --> 00:04:48,280
Now, one of the main questions that you'll
see asked on the Internet on these various

94
00:04:48,280 --> 00:04:49,910
questions is.

95
00:04:49,910 --> 00:04:51,773
Is this legal?

96
00:04:51,773 --> 00:04:56,830
Well, you know, as like many of these
things there's kind of a grey area here.

97
00:04:56,830 --> 00:05:00,686
The true honest answer at the end of
the day is that yes, it is legal.

98
00:05:00,686 --> 00:05:03,800
The emulator itself is legal,
the software is legal.

99
00:05:03,800 --> 00:05:07,292
Where we start to get into
a problem is with the IOS, right.

100
00:05:07,292 --> 00:05:10,270
Cisco routers run the Internetwork
Operating System, the IOS.

101
00:05:10,270 --> 00:05:12,525
And when you buy a Cisco router.

102
00:05:12,525 --> 00:05:19,140
You're also buying a license to run
the IOS on that router hardware.

103
00:05:19,140 --> 00:05:21,430
That means, you've licensed the IOS but

104
00:05:21,430 --> 00:05:24,188
you've only licensed it
to run on that hardware.

105
00:05:24,188 --> 00:05:26,742
You're not licensed to
run it somewhere else.

106
00:05:26,742 --> 00:05:29,547
Cisco doesn't sell just licenses for
the IOS.

107
00:05:29,547 --> 00:05:33,220
They only sell licenses for
the IOS tied to hardware.

108
00:05:33,220 --> 00:05:37,160
So when we fire up something like GNS3
it's gonna need the operating system,

109
00:05:37,160 --> 00:05:38,390
it's gonna need the IOS.

110
00:05:38,390 --> 00:05:40,300
They don't give us that cuz
they're not allowed to.

111
00:05:40,300 --> 00:05:41,980
That would be illegal.

112
00:05:41,980 --> 00:05:45,660
But if you have a copy of the IOS
from your own production routers,

113
00:05:45,660 --> 00:05:48,770
you can throw it on here and
it'll run just fine.

114
00:05:48,770 --> 00:05:50,930
But technically you're
violating your license,

115
00:05:50,930 --> 00:05:53,551
cuz your license said you were
licensed to run that software.

116
00:05:53,551 --> 00:05:58,032
On top of the Cisco hardware, not on
top of GNS3 or Dynamips or whatever,

117
00:05:58,032 --> 00:05:59,270
all right.

118
00:05:59,270 --> 00:06:01,039
So is it legal?

119
00:06:01,039 --> 00:06:03,419
Well the software is.

120
00:06:03,419 --> 00:06:06,838
Using it though requires you to pull
a Cisco license the wrong way which is

121
00:06:06,838 --> 00:06:08,420
technically not legal, right.

122
00:06:08,420 --> 00:06:10,979
You're violating the terms
of service from Cisco.

123
00:06:10,979 --> 00:06:15,160
That being said,
even Cisco uses GNS3 internally.

124
00:06:15,160 --> 00:06:17,846
So it's a very common, popular program.

125
00:06:17,846 --> 00:06:22,298
There's a lot of companies out there that
do Cisco training and they use GNS3.

126
00:06:22,298 --> 00:06:25,001
So, it's something that's
definitely known by Cisco and

127
00:06:25,001 --> 00:06:27,120
they've chosen not to
enforce that license.

128
00:06:27,120 --> 00:06:30,349
Now, one day they may change their mind,
but as of right now,

129
00:06:30,349 --> 00:06:32,417
they haven't enforced that license.

130
00:06:32,417 --> 00:06:35,842
And so many, many people,
including myself make use of the product.

131
00:06:35,842 --> 00:06:38,315
So it is a really neat one.

132
00:06:38,315 --> 00:06:42,492
Well if you want to see just kind of
a quick guided tour of it before we get it

133
00:06:42,492 --> 00:06:46,970
installed, they've got some nice
screenshots here on the website.

134
00:06:46,970 --> 00:06:50,747
And what it does is it gives you
this graphical user interface,

135
00:06:50,747 --> 00:06:52,042
this guy right here.

136
00:06:52,042 --> 00:06:55,854
The way it works is basically you have
all of these routers, firewalls, Juniper

137
00:06:55,854 --> 00:07:00,540
routers, all of these things over her on
the left; this is your network equipment.

138
00:07:00,540 --> 00:07:04,570
You just drag and drop it out here and
you link it together.

139
00:07:04,570 --> 00:07:08,350
You can link it together with
ethernet cables or serial cables,

140
00:07:08,350 --> 00:07:09,780
that's what these red
lightning bolts are here.

141
00:07:09,780 --> 00:07:10,965
These are serial cables.

142
00:07:10,965 --> 00:07:15,830
They're doing simulated T1 lines or
ISDN, or something like that.

143
00:07:15,830 --> 00:07:19,830
You can emulate technology that would be
incredibly expensive to set up in your own

144
00:07:19,830 --> 00:07:23,570
lab, and you can bring out
as many routers as you want.

145
00:07:23,570 --> 00:07:27,435
So instead of having to go to eBay and buy
a bunch of physical used routers that may

146
00:07:27,435 --> 00:07:30,339
or may not work right, here,
you just bring them right up.

147
00:07:30,339 --> 00:07:34,516
And you'll see the routers that they
support, the 1700s, those are pretty

148
00:07:34,516 --> 00:07:38,600
low-end, pretty old routers, but
they go up all the way to the 7200s.

149
00:07:38,600 --> 00:07:43,438
And the Cisco 7200, that's a beefy
router that can perform every

150
00:07:43,438 --> 00:07:47,298
single activity from the CCNA,
CCNP, and CCIE exams.

151
00:07:47,298 --> 00:07:50,435
It's a really,
really powerful router framework, so

152
00:07:50,435 --> 00:07:53,020
you really get that full feature set.

153
00:07:53,020 --> 00:07:55,008
And they don't show it
here in this screen shot,

154
00:07:55,008 --> 00:07:56,668
let me see if they have one that shows it.

155
00:07:56,668 --> 00:08:00,640
When you add a router in, you can pull
up the properties of that router and

156
00:08:00,640 --> 00:08:02,660
start to manipulate its settings.

157
00:08:02,660 --> 00:08:04,473
And, yeah they don't really show it here.

158
00:08:04,473 --> 00:08:07,571
But you can manipulate the settings
as far as inserting different WICs,

159
00:08:07,571 --> 00:08:08,700
the WAN interface cards.

160
00:08:08,700 --> 00:08:11,102
You can choose which cards you want in it,

161
00:08:11,102 --> 00:08:14,409
to make that router unique for
that particular purpose.

162
00:08:14,409 --> 00:08:16,790
You know like these routers here.

163
00:08:16,790 --> 00:08:19,758
Cisco routers don't typically come
with serial ports by default.

164
00:08:19,758 --> 00:08:23,019
So somebody's added cards into these
routers to be able to have that

165
00:08:23,019 --> 00:08:24,450
connectivity.

166
00:08:24,450 --> 00:08:25,446
You get link lights and

167
00:08:25,446 --> 00:08:28,395
information as far as whether
the connections are up and working.

168
00:08:28,395 --> 00:08:30,530
And you can start and stop the routers.

169
00:08:30,530 --> 00:08:34,363
You can back up their configurations and
build some really cool labs.

170
00:08:34,363 --> 00:08:36,880
They even have some labs available for
download on their site.

171
00:08:36,880 --> 00:08:39,010
If you look up here,
we've got this labs tab and

172
00:08:39,010 --> 00:08:42,336
you'll see here some, it looks like
they just have the Juniper ones now.

173
00:08:42,336 --> 00:08:43,760
But they're working on Cisco ones.

174
00:08:43,760 --> 00:08:46,028
I know those are coming out soon.

175
00:08:46,028 --> 00:08:48,960
But, actually that's what
they're saying right here.

176
00:08:48,960 --> 00:08:51,245
Labs will come very soon for Cisco.

177
00:08:51,245 --> 00:08:53,750
But basically it's a very
valuable resource, and

178
00:08:53,750 --> 00:08:57,370
it's a great alternative to going out and
buying the physical hardware.

179
00:08:57,370 --> 00:08:59,292
Now, can you buy the physical hardware?

180
00:08:59,292 --> 00:08:59,906
Absolutely.

181
00:08:59,906 --> 00:09:01,277
That's what I did when I got started.

182
00:09:01,277 --> 00:09:02,840
I went out and ordered eight routers.

183
00:09:02,840 --> 00:09:05,755
It cost me a ton of money,
and they were super loud and

184
00:09:05,755 --> 00:09:08,021
ate up a lot of electricity at the house.

185
00:09:08,021 --> 00:09:10,130
But that's how I learned,
over ten years ago.

186
00:09:10,130 --> 00:09:10,660
Right.

187
00:09:10,660 --> 00:09:12,093
Because we didn't have things like this.

188
00:09:12,093 --> 00:09:15,400
If I had to do it again today, I never
would've bought all that equipment, right.

189
00:09:15,400 --> 00:09:17,443
It was a lot of money
kinda down the drain.

190
00:09:17,443 --> 00:09:21,293
Versus this, where I could whip up
whatever environment I wanted and when I

191
00:09:21,293 --> 00:09:25,344
was done I could just shut it down and
it's not consuming extra power and so on.

192
00:09:25,344 --> 00:09:29,204
The other thing is it's really efficient,
we'll see this a little bit later, how it

193
00:09:29,204 --> 00:09:32,890
manages CPU and how it manages memory,
it does a really good job on those things.

194
00:09:32,890 --> 00:09:38,449
So GS3, very powerful software package,
does a lot of great things.

195
00:09:38,449 --> 00:09:39,925
Wonderful for your studies.

196
00:09:39,925 --> 00:09:43,452
All right,
that's enough of an introduction for GNS3.

197
00:09:43,452 --> 00:09:46,746
Now we're going to move into our next set
of videos, where we'll start to show how

198
00:09:46,746 --> 00:09:48,916
to get it installed and
how to actually make use of it.

199
00:09:48,916 --> 00:09:50,354
So, stay tuned.

200
00:09:50,354 --> 00:09:52,375
We'll be back with more.

201
00:09:52,375 --> 00:09:58,049
[MUSIC]
